item.description: The object of Hoppin' Poppin' Spaceballs game is to be the first player to capture four (4) Hoppin' Poppin" Spaceballs of the same color while flipping out any balls of another color. Players hit levers to knock out other-colored balls, while trying to retain balls of a selected color.

item.description:
A children's game from the 70's I would guess. A curio because this game is just a version of the linen games from Victorian times. Each player spins a spinner, moves the number of squares indicated and follows the instructions if he lands on such a square. The first to complete three laps is the winner.
Contents:
1 board
Rules (on the box insert)
4 plastic racing cars (in four colours)
i Spinner on box insert (the spinner was broken when I got this game so that is why a dice and dice cup are in one of the images)

Thermopylae is a print and play solo mini wargame representing stand of Ancient Greek soldiers against Persian invasion.
In this game you will take the role of 300 Spartans who took their last stand at Thermopylae Pass to protect retreat of the main body of Greek army.
Game can be played by using given board and counters, but if the player wishes, it can be played with miniatures on the game board, or even with chess figures on chess table (this might be a good way to find a new use for your miniature magnetic chess set while on the road). 
Game is played this by rolling a set of dices looking for doubles. Each double equals one action (move, ranged or close combat) in fight against enemy units moved by game system. Once all the enemies on the board are eliminated, new ones enter from western table edge. Game ends when all player units are eliminated, or when the first enemy unit exits board trough the eastern table edge.

Game is free, and can be downloaded from here: http://battreps.blogspot.com/2011/06/thermopylae.html

(From the website) Gavin Birnbaum's third release in the 'bouncy ball' Cubiko series sees the cubes adopting cat, mouse and cheese characters which can 'snap' together via magnets. Crafted by the designer, the game takes place on a wooden platform that represents a cheese factory. The factory has 4 zones and at the centre is the larder wherein lies the prize, a cube of cheese. The first mouse to 'nibble' (attach via the magnets) the cheese wins. You'll need a steady hand and nerves of steel to out manoeuvre the cats and you'll need good hand and eye co-ordination to make that winning shot.

Inspector Moss must investigate the mysterious death of millionaire baker, John Dough, who has been found battered at his stately country manor during a social gathering in the bachelor’s home. With an injunction in place to keep the guests from leaving, Moss has only a short window of opportunity to investigate and question the suspects. Can he eliminate the innocent and arrest the culprit before the injunction expires?

In this game, you get to play as Inspector Moss, exploring a 25-room house consisting of tiles. Each tile contains either a suspect, evidence that can be used to eliminate suspects, or something to assist you in solving the case in time.

On each turn, you roll 7 white dice and 1 colored "time" die up to 3 times. You may then use up to 6 of the dice for movement (by matching the number on the destination tile), for gathering evidence (with any 4 consecutive dice), and for getting assistance (with any 3 matching dice). After performing any actions, you must move the time marker down a number of spaces equal to the number shown on the time die plus 1 minute for every wild 6 that was used for an action.

There are 10 possible suspects in the game. Once you have collected enough evidence to eliminate 9 of them, you must arrest the remaining suspect and escort him/her to the waiting police car. If you can do all of this before time runs out, you win the game.

item.description:
A quick, humorous card game of words and imagination.

Your Word is a game in which players create their own fictional, made-up words (using the cards in their hand) to fit the theme of the round. The players’ cards contain word fragments that are used in many real English words today. Each round, a new theme sentence is revealed and the players must complete the sentence with a phrase that includes their new made-up word.

The key skill in the game is for a player to create an entertaining word from their cards which allows them to complete the theme sentence with flair and imagination, in order to impress the judge and win the round. Points are also awarded to second and third place depending upon the number of players.

The normal goal of the game is to have been awarded more points than the opposing players after one full round in which all players have had the opportunity to judge once.

The Game At A Glance: Appalachian Rails is based on the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad and its march across the coalfields of West Virginia. The railroad went into receivership after trying to burrow through difficult terrain. It was up to Colis Huntington, one of the “Big Four” in the transcontinental railroad, wanted to use the C&O as a railroad to link with his West Coast empire. Additionally, West Virginia and surrounding states in Appalachia had a large reserve of natural resources which would form the revenue stream for the C&O for years to come.

Your object is to mimic (and beat) the C&O's success.

The game starts with the player taking a loan for money to pay for track and locomotives to haul goods. Play consists of rolling dice for each commodity in the board. Some commodities such as coal are more plentiful than manufactured goods. After the commodities are placed, track is built, link by link, using the railroad's treasury. Locomotives may be purchased which have a range of anywhere from 5-10 links. After this is complete, if a player is able, he may transport cubes to any market expecting them.

There are also markets in the game which decide the price of a commodity based on how often it is delivered and how often cubes are placed on the board. These values are staggered for different cities.

For those who have played a number of train games, this game could be described as a cross between Silverton and Age of Steam with a little bit of Prairie Railroads thrown in for good measure. The main challenge of this title was to create a compelling solitaire railroading experience. The game is extremely difficult to beat. I think it lives up to the challenge.

Confusion is a card game for 2-5 players. It is a every man for himself trick after trick game. Players main goal is to be the first to empty their hand. Players play one to six card melds to attempting to win tricks. All the cards have a primary value but also have secondary purposes. Since a card(s) can only be played on a lower value card(s), winning tricks with high cards and secondary purposes of cards allow players to lead a new trick with their low value cards. A game consists of hands scored on the order in which players empty their hands. 
 
 Players can be dealt in or out as the game or social situation requires. All players have equal hand sizes to start each hand. Game play changes with the number of players playing the game (even though the rules and scoring are the same) since all the cards are dealt out each hand and depending on the number of players each player will have a different hand size even though they have the same number as all others playing that hand. 
 
 A game for a new player would take about 20 minutes from start to finish. Despite the name the game makes more and more sense as you play since many of the secondary purposes of cards are actually very intuitive. The game consists of 45 cards 4 suits and 2 un-suited cards.

item.description:
Rush Hour Scramble is a multi player competitive version of the popular solitaire puzzle game. Each player designs a Rush Hour challenge for another player to solve. Players switch boards and race to be the first to solve their challenge. The player who solves his/her challenge first is the winner.

A copy of Rush Hour is needed for each player.

item.description: Combi 4 can be played two different ways: Combi 4 SOLO and Combi 4 TOTAL. In both cases the pattern-cards are slid into the pillar. The timer is set and the pillar spins around for +/- 2 minutes. During the spinning of the pillar players have to reproduce the pattern using 16 cubes. (game introduction, translated from Dutch)

49 cards. There are six races (suits) - British, Turkish, Indian, Choctaw, Negro, Japanese. Each race has 8 ranked cards, starting with The Baby and ending with The King. The cards are also numbered from 1 to 8.
Each player gets 6 counters. Take out the Old Maid card as it is not used in the main game. Then the cards are dealt out to each player but an extra hand should also be dealt. This extra hand should remain face down and kept out of the game. Therefore, a few cards are not in play so will cause 'Stops' as the game proceeds.
The first player plays a card and announces its number and race. The next player must play the next card in rank for that race if he has it. If he doesn't then he says "I pass". There will probably come a point when the next highest card is not in play because all players will pass. In this case the player who played the last card, plays to the next round of play.
The Japanese Baby is a special card that allows the player to play it after he has just added a legal card, crying "Spin" as he does so. This means that the card he last played becomes a stop.
The game stops when one player has run out of cards. There are various rewards and forfeits and the player with the most counters wins.
Rules are included for the main game and two variants, Pool Spin and Old Maid (the publisher having added an Old Maid card for this version).

Paper-and-pencil game where from 2 to 4 players aim to score as many points as possible by crossing whole rows or columns of an 8x8 board single lines of their own colour or by crossing existing lines of the opponent.

Each turn a player throws a die and draws in his colour a single straight line crossing orthogonally as many squares as points on the die. Spaces crossed both vertically and horizontally can't be crossed anymore. For each enemy line crossed a player scores one point, for each whole row or column all in a player's colour the player scores another point. Play goes on until only single spaces can be crossed.

Use your head in this fun guessing game.

Pop a card into your opponent's headband and let them guess what they are. Ask questions to guess your animal first.

The object of the game is to travel around the board with spinning the spinner and help the Almighty Heroes accomplish their tasks and be the first to become an Almighty Hero.

Contents:

 1 Game board
 1 Spinner
 24 Game tokens
 6 Fairness tokens
 6 Faith tokens
 6 Honesty tokens
 6 Love tokens
 4 Almighty hero movers
 4 Plastic mover holders

name.value: The Amazing State Race Trivia Game

item.description:
This trivia game is an auto race across the continental U.S. by answering questions about the states. The game board poster, about 19" x 11", is a map of the U.S. with color coded paths for 4 roadsters. A correct answer advances your race car one point along the route. An incorrect answer keeps the cars stationary until next turn. The first race car to reach the end of the route (answering 10 state trivia questions correctly) wins the game.

You can develop the game further by creating your own flashcard questions about the states.

Includes 1 foldout game board, 4 game pieces, 48 state trivia cards.

KATATU is derived from a very old board game originating from the Roman Empire and passed down through Europe into Egypt and eventually to Southern Africa. Curtlin Toys and Games has created a unique version of the game which has roots to Nine Mens Morris, but has added diagonal lines to make it play better. KATATU is a 100% strategy abstract game that uses magnetic bees and grasshoppers as game pieces. The object of the game is to eliminate your opponents 'bugs' by forming 'three in a rows' or mills. By forming a three in a row you can then select an opponents game piece and remove it from the game board. Once you have gone through the stages of placing, sliding & flying the bugs you win if you have eliminated your opponent down to only two bugs (game pieces) so they cannot for a mill.

Re-implements:

 Twelve Men's Morris

item.description:
Historic Gaming #7

Hero of Weehawken is a solitaire game in which the player takes the role of President Thomas Jefferson at a dangerous moment in the history of the United States. Former Vice President Aaron Burr is somewhere out west, and rumors abound that he is threatening the nation with plans for some sort of ill-advised military adventure that could bring America to war with Spain, or even a direct act of treason against the United States!

To forestall this disaster, you must first determine Burr’s real plans, then find and arrest him before he executes his plan; and, finally, gather sufficient evidence to convict Burr at trial. If your agents arrest him too soon, you will not have gathered enough evidence or figured out what to charge him with. If you wait too long, however, you may be too late to stop his nefarious plans.

Do you have what it takes to gather the right information in time? Be the judge and become the Hero of Weehawken!

Game Data:

Complexity: 2.5 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 9 on a 9 scale
Scale: TBD

Game Components:

• One 8-page full color Rules booklet with Examples of play
• One 8.5” x 11” map
• Two 8.5” x 5.5” mats (Plan and Trial)
• One Player Aid sheet
• 32 5/8" square game pieces
• 60 Event cards

item.description:
The King's birthday has arrived! Wealthy aristocrats from across the land have gathered to throw a lavish ball in the King's honor, sparing no expense in an attempt to impress him. Of course, everyone knows that the best way to impress a father is to win the favor of his daughters. At the ball, one more bit of business needs to be settled – each aristocrat has bet a parcel of land that he can curry the most favor from the seven sisters over the course of the party! With their land and honor on the line, each aristocrat is rushing to gain the favor of the daughters, and to cast derision on his opponents.

In Seven Sisters, a hand-management, area-control Euro-style board game, the players play the roles of wealthy aristocrats who are trying to gain the favor of the king's seven daughters, who happen to be named after the seven deadly sins: Wrath, Greed, Gluttony, Lust, Sloth, Pride, and Envy.
 
The game consists of four rounds, with the players being dealt six cards each round. Using five of the six cards, players influence the sisters by sending servants to do the sisters' bidding. Multiple options when playing each card create opportunities for players to use both strategic and tactical play to influence the sisters more than their opponents do.

Each round after cards are played, scoring occurs with each sister granting her favor (victory point) and a special reward or action to the player who has influenced her most that round. These rewards and actions are thematically tied to the name of the sister (e.g., Greed rewards players with gold). Gaining this favor is important not only for the victory point, but also to gain advantages and resources for following rounds.

After four rounds are played and scored, another scoring round happens immediately. Victory points are tallied, including bonus points for having gained the favor of all seven sisters and for having the highest quantity of unused resources remaining (gold, fruit, and servants). The player with the most points wins!

name.value: Have-A-Go, The Wilfred Pickles Radio Party Game

item.description:
Trivia game linked to a very popular radio quiz hosted by Wilfred Pickles.

11 cards with 6 different questions on each one
1 Jackpot card
Rules

With so few questions provided, the replayability is very low.

A trivia game, with 12 nunbered cards, on each of which are 6 General Knowledge questions. Play as teams. Replayability is not good but I guess the intention is to break the ice at parties, so it does exactly that.

Distribute the cards all round the room where the party is being held. Guests are encouraged to mingle and, whilst chatting, note down the answers to the 12 cartoon images. Each image depicts a character doing something - the guests have to work out what.

Party word game. Each player gets a card. Now the agreed starting player calls out a letter and all the players must fill in one of their 25 squares with that letter. Then the next player calls out a letter, and so on, until everyone's grid is complete. Longer words score better than shorter words, and the one with the most points, wins.

On each card there are 4 grids. A is the main game but B, C and D can be used for variety. The only difference is that the solid squares will limit the letter placement.

Party game.
The host places syllables all round the room. Players are instructed to find three syllables that make up the name of a British town; e.g. Ed-in-burgh. There are 33 towns listed on the host's Key Card, all made up of three syllables.
If you can make a town out of the syllables, you take it to the host who records you with 1 success and he will put the cards back in the box. Then the successful player goes back to the room to see if he can find another town.
After an agreed time, the player who found the most, wins.

A card game, with 64 cards. These cards name a country (called a Key Card) or name a place associated with that country. For example, Italy has six cards associated with the country; Italy itself, Rome, Naples, Turin, Milan, and Venice. The Key Cards plus their associated cards are not the same in number for each country. Some will be more than six, some less.
Play is similar but not completely the same to many other set collecting games.
Once a set has been completed it is placed aside and scored when the game ends. It is suggested that 3 rounds should be played, and the highest score, wins.
The rules suggest that the game will give you a good knowledge of geography and will reward those players with a good memory.

Paper-and-pencil game where from 2 to 4 players aim to score as many points as possible by crossing existing lines of the opponent on an 8x8 board. Each player starts at one edge of the board (the starting field is the second to the right).

Each turn a player can draw in his colour a straight line crossing orthogonally one or two fields, or a bent line (one field crossed - corner on the next field - one field crossed). Spaces with corners or crossed both vertically and horizontally can't be crossed anymore. For each enemy line crossed a player scores one point. If one player's line can't be continued, they can start from another "free" square at their edge of the board. Play goes on until all players have used up their eight possible starting fields.

Paper-and-pencil game where from 2 to 4 players must score the most possible points after marking the fifth dot (later cross) on a row or column of an 8x8 board.

A round consists of two phases: in the first phase players mark in turns a square on the board with a dot - the first one to mark the fifth square in a row, column or main diagonal scores as many points as dots drawn by the other players in that row, column or main diagonal. In the second phase players mark free squares in similar fashion but with crosses; the first player to mark the fifth cross in a row, column or main diagonal scores as many points as crosses drawn by the other players in that row, column or main diagonal.

A Decktet memory game for two children.

From the Decktet wiki:

On your turn, declare "I am searching for ..." and name the suit from one of the unclaimed aces. Then move your token one card clockwise and turn over the card your token lands on, revealing it for everyone to see. If that card has the suit you were searching for, claim the ace of that suit - unless it was a Crown, which causes you to put back in the middle of the table the claimed ace of the Crown's suit if you have currently claimed it. The excuse does nothing when one of the face-down cards.

The younger player goes first, unless the game was just played and someone one, in which case the previous game's loser goes first. Players take turns until all six aces are claimed. The player who claims the most aces wins. If both players claim three aces the game is a draw.

In Corundum, this game is called 'Conundrum Terrapin'. This may be because, as in Terrapin, something happens when every suit is present in a group of cards. But it may instead be because of court politics, which render people in Corundum unable to use the proper name for anything. People outside Corundum call the game 'Corundum Conundrum' - except the tongue-tied Bhargivians, who call it 'Conungrem'.

Conundrum is a partnership trick-taking game for the Decktet for 4 in teams of 2 sitting opposite each other. The goal of the game is to take the most cards possible in the most tricks possible.

This game teaches investors the difference between investments and corresponding risks.

Each player receives a sum of money and can invest in either shares, bonds, real estate, gold or..., depending on his movement on the board. The game controls the influence of the stock-market by event cards.

The game ends in a predefined time of when several rounds (years) are passed, the winner is the player with the best return of value

item.description:
In the game of Nile, you and your opponent are rival builders of the great pyramids, using your workers to collect resources and build pyramids.

Nile is a 2-player worker placement game where players compete for resources and workers in order to build the best and most pyramids. Played with Icehouse pyramids, Nile is one of the first Euro-style games to come out of the Icehouse system.

Rules here: http://icehousegames.org/wiki/index.php?title=Nile

item.description:
A Custom Monopoly Board Game for Laguna Beach, California.
The object of LagunaOpoly game is to become the wealthiest resident of Laguna Beach by buying, operating, and selling local businesses. The game ends when all but one Enterpriser has gone broke. This remaining player is the WINNER of the game.

Contents:

 1 Game board
 28 Business ownership deeds
 16 Risk cards
 16 Laguna treasure cards
 16 Plastic hotels
 28 Plastic houses
 1 Set of money
 4 Bowling pin pawns
 2 Standard 6-sided dice

In this game, each player wears a vinyl headband which holds two cards. The cards form a two-digit number, and the object of the game is to guess the number on your head. This is done by calling out numbers and having the other players tell you "high" or "low," with the information being tracked on a vinyl board. A round is won by the first person to guess their number, and the first person to win three rounds wins the game.

Coin Rail Yard is a Solitaire game (1 player) where the player will take on the duties of the yardmaster for the game's Rail Yard. The player will operate the Locomotives which will break-down arriving Trains and build-up departing Trains.
 The player will run through one of the sixteen scenarios, keeping track of how many turns that it took to complete the day's work. The final score will be determined by the number of turns plus any penalty occurred for mistakes. 
 There is a small amount of randomness in the game. There is also some flexibility in how the rail cars are arranged in the yard before the first Train arrives. This randomness and flexibility means that a scenario need not play out the same way the second time through. The game also comes with the guidelines for how to generate your own scenarios.
 Several expansion maps are planned.

name.value: Hulk Hogan's Rock 'n' Wrestling Card Game

item.description:
Hulk Hogan's Rock 'n' Wrestling Card Game is a game in which players try to improve their hand of cards by drawing the top card of either the face-down draw pile or the face-up discard pile, and discarding either that card or one of the four cards in their hand. Except for Flip cards, each card has a point value in the range of 3 to 10, or 0. If a player discards a Flip card when they do not have the advantage, then they take the advantage from the other player. Only the player with the advantage is able to call a Showdown, at which time both sides reveal their hands; the player with the highest point total wins the match.

The four-player game plays much like the two-player game, with the major difference being that the player who calls for a Showdown must beat the hands of both of his opponents.

item.description:
A press-your-luck game of fraught cuisine for the Decktet.

Flip a card face up and then flip another. Continue until there are cards showing four or more of the six Decktet suits.

Active players simultaneously indicate whether they intend to take a bowl now or wait for more ingredients.

If the additional card makes it so that the face up cards include at least one instance of each of the six Decktet suits, then the soup has gone Turtle Butt. The soup night is over. Return any chips in the pot to the bank. Players who didn't take a bowl get nothing for that night.

The game should be played for at least five soup nights. Obviously, you can make the game longer by playing more nights. In the end, each small chip collected is worth 1 point and each large chip is worth 5. The player with the most points wins.

Because the world needs more games about dueling wizards.

You are an ancient and powerful wizard living in a community for aged but powerful wizards. The guy across the way bubbles his cauldron much too loud, even though you have asked him to turn it down several times. There was a time when those who disturbed your afternoon tea would feel the force of your eldritch wrath. Perhaps this afternoon will be such a time.

The uses a copy of the Decktet and one Rainbow Pyramid stash for each player. (That's a small, medium, and large pyramid in each of five colours: Red, Yellow, Green, Blue, and Black. Two players can play with an Ice Dice set or two Treehouse sets.) Cards represent spells you have in mind; in the game, this means attacks you can make. Pyramids are your circle of magical instruments; they are what you need to have in place to play cards. Your opponent will whittle away at your pyramids, and you at theirs. The first player to run out of pyramids loses.

name.value: Who is The Doctor?: Demon's Run Standoff

item.description:
‘Demons run when a good man goes to war.’
This is an unauthorised, non-profit, print-and-play game inspired by the BBC TV show Doctor Who episode ‘A Good Man Goes to War’ (Series 6, Episode 7). The basic game mechanism is a kind of reverse werewolf/mafia game where the secret character, The Doctor, is the only person who can’t kill anyone and has to survive on wits and confusion alone.

Background: (Or buy the DVD and watch it!)
Human soldiers and the mysterious headless monks are working together in an uneasy alliance. They have kidnapped The Doctor’s companion (Amy Pond) and taken her to the asteroid know a Demon’s Run. The Doctor arrives on the asteroid disguised as one of the monks but reveals himself and demands Amy’s return. The lights go out and then back on, all orchestrated by the doctor, of course. Now the soldiers are stood there facing the monks. The soldiers know that one of the monks is their feared enemy, The Doctor, determined to foil their plans. All they have to do is to work out which monk is The Doctor in disguise and shoot him before he escapes. But if they shoot the wrong monk they will feel the wrath of their allies and be killed themselves by the monks dying blast. The monks themselves know that the soldiers are trigger happy and might shoot them. It might be best for them to zap any of the trigger happy soldiers before they themselves are killed - at least the other soldiers would know that they were a monk and not The Doctor. But the monks’ plan needs the soldiers and if they lose all of their soldiers then their plans will fail and The Doctor will triumph. The soldiers and monks need to act quickly before The Doctor is able to escape. The scene is set for the Demon’s Run Standoff.

The Game:
The players take on the role of soldiers, headless monks and The Doctor through a series of standoffs. During each standoff: the soldiers try to kill The Doctor; the monks try to direct the soldiers to The Doctor, and The Doctor just tries to survive. At the end of the standoff, points are given to players whose characters are still alive.

This game was made as a fundraiser for the Accents of Sheboygan, a color guard team. The spaces on the board are business sponsors or lists of individual sponsors, featuring such historical local classics as Zurheide's Ice Cream and Prange's, neither of which still exist. The trivia cards are a mix of general trivia and Sheboygan history.

Roll the dice and move. The first to answer 12 questions correctly gets to try to answer a question from the Jackpot. The first to answer a question from the Jackpot wins.

C. C. Higgins Rail Pass is a railroad board game that lets you relive the excitement of a railroad executive in the heyday of rail travel.

Basically a roll-and-move game without the dice, passes may be used to facilitate free rail travel. Collect color-coded sets of rail passes as you travel the rails of North American railroad companies of 1920. Plan your routes as you race to designated payday cities utilizing the free travel from the rail passes you obtain along the way. The goal of the game is to garner the most points by combining rail passes into various sets defined by having the most passes in color categories and types of Railroads. C. C. Higgins Rail Pass is a completely luck-free strategy game that is both simple and extremely flexible in play.

3 in a row makes TRIPOLO.

Wherever you spot 2 similar cards in a row, play a matching card from your hand to make it a "TRIPOLO" — 3 in a row horizontally, vertically, or diagonally. Act fast to be the first player to get rid of all your cards.

Make matches as fast as you can!

item.description:
Keel-Hauled! is a dice game for 2 to 4 players. Although the game does contain some complexity, it is relatively simple to learn. Play time for a full game of 50 points is usually less than an hour.

Players are pirates who vie for the position of Captain on a pirate ship. To to this, players must roll their dice to assemble sets that first match the number on the "Crew Dice" which represent the Cabin Boy, Ship's Cook, and First Mate. This becomes more challenging as there are limited spaces on the boat for dice sets to be placed, and the first player can change throughout the game.

The game is normally continued until one player scores 30 to 50 points, when the player with the most points overall is dubbed the new Captain of the ship.

Keel-Hauled has been discontinued, and is no longer available at The Game Crafter website.

item.description:
Played similar with UNO.
The aim is to empty your hand of all cards. When playing with 2 players deal 7 cards each. When with 3 or more deal 6 cards each. The remaining stack of cards are placed in front of the players face down and the top card is them turned over and placed next to the stack.
There are plenty of special cards in this game:
When a "Pick 2"or "Pick 5" card is played, the next player must draw 2or 5 cards or play another 2 card,
"Skip Turn" skips turn.
"Bullet Proof" card blocks any skip or pick card.

Contents:

 52 cards

Shuffle deck. Deal out to each player one card at a time until all cards are dealt out. Each player checks their cards and discards all pairs. The player to the left of dealer offers their hand to the player on their left hiding cards from their view. That player then takes one card from the hand. Again, any pairs are discarded. Playing continues. "The Boss" card can be passed around several times. The object is to be left with "The Boss" card. Finally, when all pairs are laid down, there will be one person left with "The Boss" card. That person is "Boss of ‘The Family’".

The hare and tortoise are staging a series of races! This an asymmetric 2 player climbing race game using the Decktet system. Even though the players must shed the same amount of cards, the Hare is given much more to use (and is more free to use them) at the start of the game, but the Tortoise will slowly and steadily build up her hand.

The card play like climbing games is in response to the opponent's plays, but it is also constrained because the players must always connect their plays with their developing race tracks. The winner with the best record after four races is the champion badger!

Full rules may be found on wiki.decktet.com

Pass safely through the traffic! Policeman Paul help players: There are many different picture cards to for close examination. Whoever assesses the traffic situation correctly will move ahead. Traffic lights, zebra crossings, footpaths and road game - this game teaches children how to behave in traffic and gain independence.

---

German Box Back
Sicher durch den Verkehr! Polizist Paul hilft spielerisch dabei: Viele verschiedene Bildkarten regen zum genauen Hinsehen an. Wer die Verkehrs-Situationen richtig einschätzt, kommt gut voran. Ampel, Zebrastreifen, Fußweg und Spielstraße - mit diesem Spiel lernen Kinder das richtige Verhalten im Verkehr und gewinnen an Selbstständigkeit

item.description:
Quick Quest distills dungeon delving into its basic elements: killing monsters and looting treasure. Level up you heroes, equip your items, and venture deeper into the dungeon. Can your party survive to level 10? If they do there's a nasty boss and evil minions waiting there for you.

Designed for solo play but easily adapted to multiplayer, Quick Quest is a fast-paced fantasy card and dice game that only takes about 30 minutes to play.

You might not always have time enough for an RPG but there's always time for a Quick Quest.

Includes:
Hero Cards Deck (8 cards)
Treasure Deck (43 cards)
Quest Treasure Deck (17 cards)
Monster Deck (68 cards)
Quick Quest Rules Document
1 D12 (17mm) - Random Color
2 D6 (16mm) - Black
2 D6 (16mm) - Blue
2 D6 (16mm) - Red
3 D6 (16mm) - White
2 D6 (16mm) - Yellow
25 Poker Chips (22mm) - Red

item.description:
The batlle continues between the lonesome cowboy and the most notorious outlaws in the West. This game is a battle of wits, with Lucky Luke and his faithful steed Jolly Jumper on one side, and the Dalton brothers and Ma Dalton on the other.

The game consists of a plastic board, 8 squares by 8, on which are placed 64 counters. The orange counters represent Lucky Luke and Jolly Jumper. The purple counters the Dalton brothers and Ma Dalton.

Rules: the game is for 2 players. The aim is to get 5 counters in a row (4 Lucky Luke + Jolly Jumper or 4 Daltons + Ma Dalton)
Each player puts down one counter at a time, and his opponent must try to stop him making a line, ath the same time gaining points himself. each complete line is worth 1 point, and the player with the highest number of points is the winner

Derelicts of Sin: Heresy is the first in a series of games revolving around the Derelicts of Sin and the dark past of the Theocratic Council.

Heresy revolves around Kyle Mason, the sole survivor of a terrible act of sabotage. Hoping to find oxygen before he asphyxiates, Kyle limps his sabotaged ship into a forbidden Cursed Zone called "the Wreckage." There, he boards one of the Derelicts of Sin, the Heresy, desperate to find the supplies he needs to survive and return home.

This solo game seeks to recreate the feel of classic text-based adventures. The player takes on the role of engineer Kyle Mason. Oxygen is used as action points to move, open locked doors, restore power, etc. The player begins on the Airlock tile. As he or she explores the ship, additional tiles are drawn randomly and added to the ship. These tiles provide instructions on how to further advance, reveal the items that can be found in the new room, and detail the the puzzle(s), if any, that must be solved in order to win the game.

In the current version, a player sheet is used to track the player's physical and mental states (which affect the player's ability to search the ship and perform various actions), as well as the player's oxygen level and inventory. Another optional version is in development that will use chart tiles and tokens to track these things.

As the player explores the ship, he or she will find data cards that gradually reveal the terrible fate of the Heresy and its passengers and crew. They also provide victory points that are key to obtaining the specific ending a player desires. Without sufficient victory points, players will lose when they end the game, so it's important to find as many data cards as possible.

This game was developed as part of the Solitaire Print-and-Play Contest at http://boardgamegeek.com/thread/644090/solitaire-print-and-play-contest/page/1.

Game Overview

In Atlantida you control a faction of the people of Atlantis that, after a series of catastrophes that turn their once glorious civilization to a semi-barbaric state, must move to the safety of the continent to avoid perish in the island inevitable collapse.
There are 13 turns, in which you must explore the island to gather resources, develop your city and discover technologies and advances in order to be able to send your population to safety. The winner is the first to save all her people or the most efficient to save them in the moment the island collapses.

Game Development

Even though the Atlantida already works as intended and the general idea is defined, it is still subject to changes. The game was developed directly for the yucata.de website, aiming to benefit from multiple plays which can provide a fair amount of players' feedback and suggestions. It is possible to play it "live", though, using the print and play files and rules at the Files section.

item.description:
In Air-musement Park the ride through the amusement park can be played alone or with others. Single players can work through each maze to improve their skills and improve their time. With multiple players, time each player's attempt and the player with the best time wins! If the player loses air control of the ball, the player must start over. Players can physically move around
each maze as they manipulate the ball through each challenge run; however, the player can not touch or move the maze itself.

Game where math skills, color blending, critical thinking and fast-paced, finger-flicking fun meet.

This intriguing game is a fun way for children to explore combinations and blends of colors. For example, by shifting the yellow and blue levers, they guide a marble into the green slot. By shifting the red, yellow and white levers, they guide a marble into the peach slot. To win, all slots must be filled with two marbles of matching colors. It's a great test of visual tracking, mental aerobics and hand-eye coordination.

Contents:

 1 Plastic game board




(with 32 marbles, 2 plastic legs
and wind-up timer)

This silly word game includes 80 game cards. Players take turns describing the object (noun) on each card without saying the word on the card. The first person that guesses the correct word wins the card. When a player gets a card with a green alligator they give clues to the other players to help them guess the activity (verb) the alligator is doing. The person who correctly
guesses the most cards wins.

The object of Pool Party game is to be the first player to bring their frogs (disks) into a row, starting from the smaller inner circle next to the island and continuing in a straight line out to the largest circle is the winner. Which frolicking frog will be first to hop in and form a row in the pool? Only the dice can say. This suspenseful game encourages kids to call on their thinking, basic math and social skills.

Contents:

 1 Game board
 30 Frogs (disks)




(Each disk size is in 6 colors: red, blue, green, purple, orange, yellow)
5 Large disks (1-3/16")
5 Semi-large disks (1-1/16")
5 Medium disks (7/8")
5 Semi-medium disks (13/16")
5 Small disks (19/32")

 2 Standard 6-sided dice

Look carefully! These images are very similar and as players match picture cards to them they develop concentration, observation, and critical thinking skills. Players match the picture cards with the pictures on their boards. The quickest player is the winner.

Contents:

 4 Game boards




1 Balls game board
1 Cat game board
1 Clown game board
1 Tomato game board

 36 Lotto picture cards




9 Balls lotto cards
9 Cat lotto cards
9 Clown lotto cards
9 Tomato lotto cards

 1 Check sheet

Unique charade card game where the players have to throw a dice and then depending of the number that comes up have the possibility to have drawn the same amount of pictures to figure out whats on the other players card.
The dice rolls... and it is a «2»! The player has the right to 2 drawings in order to make you guess by association of ideas, the object drawn on his card.

Contents:

 100 cards featuring 600 objects in all, 
 5 pads of paper, 
 5 pencils
 2 special dice.
The player throws the 3 dices . If he obtains the combination "B.O.A" he wins cards to enlarge his snake. The largest Boa wins

A luminous observation game: The cards all look the same at first glance, so it's not so easy to pair them up.

Object of the game is create as many pairs as You can. Players mix the cards then place them on the table with the "5 geometric forms" side facing upwards. All the players play at the same time. Once the signal is given, each player looks at the cards and tries to find identical pairs. As soon as a player thinks he has created a pair, he takes two cards, places them in front of him and continues to search for other pairs. But watch out for mistakes as the cards are very similar!In fact, all the cards contain the 5 same geometric shapes; only their location differs from one card to the other. You are not allowed to touch the cards except to finally take them!

Game ends when there are no more cards in the centre of the table, or it does not seem possible to create another pair (if the players have taken incorrect pairs), each player checks the pairs that he has created. Winner is the player with the most correct pairs.

Components:

 48 luminous cards

The world as you knew it has collapsed, flesh eating horrors from your worst nightmares walk the earth, and you're low on ammo..

Welcome to Zed by Dawn.

Object:
Zed by Dawn is a print-and-play solo survival horror dice and card game in the world of Zed Run!!! Before the Citystates, before the Gameshow, there were survivors that tirelessly fought the undead hordes; ZbD pits you against a world gone mad.

Zbd's Combat system requires the player to meet or exceed a number of successes that match the encounters target number, using a custom set of six-sided dice.

Each roll whether it be all six dice or just one die will use the survivors precious resources, Fatigue is use to perform melee attacks, ammo is used to perform ranged attacks and if your survivor is ever out of these resources, they cannot use the matching weapon.

Weapons will lower the needed number of successes to defeat encounters.

Items will be used to replenish your survivors resource pools.

Events encountered will hinder your advancement.

Survive to draw the last card in the ZbD deck and made it through the night. But what will tomorrow bring.

You must manage your resources, acquire supplies, and defeat an endless army of the walking dead; your only goal is to survive.

What you need to play
72 ZbD Cards
6 Survivor Cards
3 Resource Tracking dice (d20)
6 Combat dice (d6)

Pirate Polo is a frantic live-action game for 2 - 4 "pirates". The game is played using a mini-trampoline as the playing surface. Each player has 5 dice of a single, unique color. In the center of the mini-trampoline is set a heavy, non-fragile cereal bowl. The players space themselves evenly around the mini-trampoline and place all five of their dice on the game surface in front of them. Each player has a polo mallet (at times also known as a serving spoon). On the starting signal, all players strike underneath the mini-trampoline with their polo mallet to try to propel their dice into the bowl. The first player to get all 5 dice in the bowl is the winner. This game is an alternative to the difficult to obtain Piratenbillard.

This electronic talking quiz game challenges kids with fast-paced high tech fun! High quality digital Texas Instruments voice technology asks questions about world countries, rivers, mountains, landmarks and more. Over 7,500 intriguing questions! Unit updates scores and provides positive reinforcement.

Contents:

 1 Electronic game unit features four light-up Play buttons for one to four players. Unit updates scores and provides positive reinforcement.

Academe is a quick, cooperative, filler card game for 3 players: one Thinker, one Teacher and one Builder. The players must expend and earn Ideas, Knowledge and Material by building inventions. Possible inventions are determined by turning over cards in rounds, and the player must choose which invention to build in each turn. If, by the end of the three rounds of the game, the team has earned enough of these three commodities to build a University, they win the game.

Because it is non-competitive, it can also be easily played by fewer than 3 people, if one player wants to play more than one character. In addition, the commodity targets can be lowered to make the game easy to win, for young children.

item.description:
A card game based on the popular game MiYu.

Players collect elements of a magic circles by discarding sets of 3 cards. A set is made of 1 (out of 4) element, a Zodiac sign associated to that element and the corresponding stone.

The game includes joker cards that, when rubbed by a player, reveal a message as by magic!

Players roll 2 dice and try to match the sum of the dice in his bingo sheet (numbers 2-12). Player who fills his sheet first is the winner

Contents:

 score pad, 
 2 dice, 
 cup

Players compete to accumulate the most tiles using a combination of memory, alertness and luck. When a 'Run' of 4 tiles in a row appears, the first to yell 'Snag!' is entitled to place them in his winnings pile. Players maneuver 80 wooden pieces on the board. Object of the game is outwit and outguess the opponents.

Game description from the publisher:

It is 1926, and the museum's extensive collection of exotic curios and occult artifacts poses a threat to the barriers between our world and the elder evils lurking between dimensions. Gates to the beyond begin to leak open, and terrifying creatures of increasing strength steal through them. Animals, the mad, and those of more susceptible minds are driven to desperation by the supernatural forces the portals unleash. Only a handful of investigators race against time to locate the eldritch symbols necessary to seal the portals forever. Only they can stop the Ancient One beyond from finding its way to Earth and reducing humanity to cinders.

Elder Sign is a fast-paced, cooperative dice game of supernatural intrigue for one to eight players by Richard Launius and Kevin Wilson, the designers of Arkham Horror. Players take the roles of investigators racing against time to stave off the imminent return of the Ancient One. Armed with tools, allies, and occult knowledge, investigators must put their sanity and stamina to the test as they adventure to locate Elder Signs, the eldritch symbols used to seal away the Ancient Ones and win the game.

To locate Elder Signs, investigators must successfully endure Adventures within the museum and its environs. A countdown mechanism makes an Ancient One appear if the investigators are not quick enough. The investigators must then battle the Ancient One. A clever and thematic dice mechanism pits their exploration against monsters and the sheer difficulty of staying sane and healthy, all within the standard game duration of one to two hours.

item.description:
Red Baron is a low complexity, quick playing board game of World War I air combat. This is not an aerial combat simulation by any means. It is a relatively simple "beer & pretzels" game in which the players use cards to fly their fighters, bombers, and balloons.

The game is two-dimensional (no altitude considerations) and features three aircraft types (fighters, bombers and balloons). Players use cards to maneuver their aircraft (one per card play) with the aim of collecting victory points by shooting down enemy aircraft, bombing ground targets (with bombers) or conducting aerial observation over no man's land (with balloons). The players each start with six aircraft but can vary the assortment in an effort to pursue differing victory strategies.

The game comes packaged in a ziploc bag that contains the 11" by 17" card-stock (unmounted) board, 38 playing pieces (counters), 28 cards and 4 pages of rules.

This football strategy game revolves around a pair of selector cups, one for each player. The cups are built into the thick gridiron board and function as dials that determine the play selected by each coach.

The outcome of each offensive play is determined by die rolls in the selector cups. The offensive team rolls for yardage gained. The defensive player rolls two dice that can generate random events like a fumble or a penalty.

Play follows the rules of football with punts, field goals, and every other element of the sport.

The board includes a sliding football marker and a matching first down marker that also slides up and down the field. There is a huge scoreboard plus the rulebook.

Published in 1978 by Wildcard, Inc.

This is a simple roll and move game of the TT Races on the Isle of Man. The players take turns rolling dice and moving around the board, a 'satellite photo' style representation of the TT Races course. At various points they encounter obstacles that may slow them down or speed them up. They may land on spaces that cause them to draw Race Situation or Pit Signal cards which can affect their progress positively or negatively.

The game components as listed on the rules card are:

Board (TT Course)
Eight playing pieces of different colours (small plastic motorcycles)
One Throwing/Equipment Holder Box
Two Dice
Once Dice Cup
Six sets of Lap Scoring Cards (each numbered 1 - 6)
Sixty-six Race Situation cards
Sixty-four Pit Signal cards

name.value: The National Game of the Star-Spangled Banner

item.description: An educational game based on an earlier British game. One of the first games published in the USA.

Unpack the whole cycling world on your table! Enter the strategies of the biggest cycling teams in a great family game Arrivée.

Compete in the stages for the jerseys of the best cyclist, World champion, best climber, best sprinter or U-25. 
The game realistically simulates all point and bonus awards of the major cycling races of the world. 
As you ride each stage, time is measured so that you can know what advantage or loss you have in comparison with your competitors. 
Your journey to victory can become complicated due to sudden weather changes, falls or defects, but team co-operation can help you back to the pack. Refresh your team and have the best performance with the use of a dice, cards and intuitive game mechanism.

Arrivée is the best simulation of cycling race stages in the world!

item.description:
This is game #6 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series.

F.I.L.O is a sowing game like those in the Mancala family. Unlike games normally found in the Mancala family, F.I.L.O uses a first in, last out (FILO) mechanism for sowing pieces on the board, which is the basis of its name. This mechanism, combined with the attributes of the 8x4 board, takes F.I.L.O in directions not normally seen with games in the Mancala family.

This is #7 in the Games on a Half a Checkerboard Series. Frontjammin' is a game like Backgammon, with its own twists. It also includes a variant using a King piece, which gives the game a bit of a Chess flavor.

In the game, players will roll two dice. If they roll 5-6 on any of the two dice, that counts as a single die roll that a player picks (1-4). If players roll doubles of 1-4, they advance 4 pieces the same amount, if possible.

In addition, the game involves pieces being placed in columns and trapping their opponent's pieces. The smaller board also lends to an increased chance of a reversal of fortune.

This is game #8 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series.

2-5 Skidoo a press-your-luck game for 2 players on an 8x4 board, in the family of games that includes games like Can't Stop, Cosmic Wimpout, 500, Farkle, Ten Thousand, and Pass the Pigs. The name is derived from the phrase “23 skidoo”.

In this game, each of the 4 columns on the 4x8 board correspond to numbers 2-5. During a turn a player rolls 6 six-sided dice (numbered 1-6). They pick three to add up, to beat a target number (this is either zero on their first roll, or what their last total was). The players then take one of the remaining 3 dice and apply it to one of their columns.

If a player can't apply a die to advance one of their pieces, or don't beat their target number, all advancement resets.

Play continues until a player gets all four of their pieces off the board.

This is #9 game in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series.

In Melting Ice Floes, players attempt to eliminate their opponent's pawn or ice floe pieces from the board. As the game progresses, the board shrinks and players may face a situation where half of the board suddenly disappears on them, leaving them with every increasing dangerous situations from which to escape. This game comes with variant rules to support 3 and 4 players.

This is game #10 in the Games on Half a Checkerboard Series

This game is in the family of games that includes Amazons, and Slimetrail where the object is to cause one's opponent to not be able to move due to the number of spaces available on the board gets reduced as players play the game. Each player has a piece that has a move like a Chess Knight and also put down barricades to restrict movement. From these two elements comes the name of the game.

Sherlock is a cooperative memory game in which players try to unmask the culprit by collecting cards that exonerate the remaining suspects.

To set up the game, thirty cards are shuffled and placed face-down in a 6x5 grid. Each card shows one of six witnesses on its back and a witness viewing one of the five suspects on its front. On a turn, the active player reveals two cards in the grid. If they match, the player then turns over a third card. If all three cards show show the same suspect, the cards are collected and placed face-up next to the grid. In all other cases, that player turns the cards face-down once again, then flips over one of the ten timing cards, each showing Sherlock's nemesis Moriarty.

If all ten Moriarty cards are flipped, then the players lose the game. If, however, the players remove cards from the grid until only three remain, they have successfully identified the culprit – that is, the suspect who remains – and can claim victory.

A competitive variant is included in the rules which have players competing to collect witness cards. An additional variant rewards points to the player who holds (or doesn't hold) the suspect eventually identified as the culprit.

The Sherlock box also includes eight bonus cards, a new dinosaur and action cards for a fifth player for Ilopeli's Jurassik.

name.value: Shopping, el juego de la moda

item.description: The goal of the game is to get ten clothing and fashion items, by answering questions related to the fashion and glamour world. When you annswer correctly, you get money, with which to buy the items you need. After several rounds, the final phase of the game consists in a final question. Depending on how good your item selection was, the answer will be easier or more difficult.
